metadata.name: Weather
metadata.disclaimer: This information provides general wilderness weather survival guidance. It is not a substitute for professional training. Use your judgment and adapt to real conditions.

entries.title: Hypothermia Prevention
entries.summary: Recognize early signs of hypothermia and take steps to retain heat, stay dry, and preserve energy in cold environments.
steps: Layer clothing: use a moisture-wicking base layer, insulating mid-layer, and windproof/water-resistant outer layer.
Keep clothing dry. Swap wet clothing as soon as possible; wring out moisture or use body heat to dry small items.
Cover extremities: wear a hat, gloves, and warm socks to prevent rapid heat loss.
Stay off bare ground by sitting or lying on insulating materials such as a foam pad, pine boughs, or clothing.
Keep moving in short intervals to maintain circulation without sweating; sweat increases heat loss.
Eat high-energy foods (nuts, chocolate, dried fruit) and drink warm fluids if possible to fuel heat production.
If symptoms occur (shivering, confusion, slurred speech), seek shelter immediately and add insulation.
do_not: Do not drink alcohol; it increases heat loss and impairs judgment.
Do not ignore early shivering or numbness; these are warning signs.
Do not overexert to the point of sweating; wet clothing accelerates hypothermia.
watch_for: Uncontrollable shivering, loss of coordination, slurred speech.
Cold, pale, or rigid extremities.
Irrational behavior or apathy, signs of moderate to severe hypothermia.
notes: Wind chill dramatically speeds heat loss; prioritize wind protection even when temperatures seem mild.
Insulation works best when dry and fluffy—regularly shake out lofted materials.
Shelter and fire become critical if you are cold AND wet.

entries.title: Frostbite
entries.summary: Identify early frostbite and take safe steps to warm affected areas without causing additional tissue damage.
steps: Check exposed skin frequently, especially fingers, toes, nose, cheeks, and ears.
Look for pale, waxy, numb, or hard skin—these are signs of frostbite.
Move to shelter or block wind with a jacket, pack, or terrain feature.
Warm affected areas gradually using body heat (armpits, against warm skin, spare dry mittens).
Replace wet gloves or socks with dry materials if available.
If rewarming begins, keep the area warm; repeated freezing after thawing causes severe damage.
Avoid walking on frostbitten feet unless absolutely necessary; pressure can worsen injury.
do_not: Do not rub frostbitten skin; this causes tissue tearing.
Do not heat with open flames, stoves, or boiling water; burning is easy when numb.
Do not rewarm if the area may freeze again; wait until sustained warmth is possible.
watch_for: Skin turning red or purple as it rewarms (normal), but watch for severe swelling or blisters.
Loss of sensation persisting after warming.
Cold exposure combined with dehydration or exhaustion, which increases risk.
notes: Prevention is easier than treatment—cover all exposed skin in wind and sub-freezing temperatures.
Frostnip (early stage) is reversible; full frostbite requires medical care when available.

entries.title: Heatstroke Prevention
entries.summary: Manage hydration, shade, and exertion to avoid overheating in hot climates.
steps: Limit activity during the hottest part of the day (10 a.m. to 4 p.m.); schedule movement for mornings and evenings.
Stay in shade as much as possible; create shade using a tarp, branches, or reflective blankets.
Drink water frequently in small sips; combine with electrolytes if you have salt packets or mineral tablets.
Wear loose, light-colored clothing that allows airflow and protects from direct sun.
Cool pulse points by soaking a scarf or cloth with water and applying it to the neck, armpits, or groin.
Rest at regular intervals whenever your breathing or heart rate climbs noticeably.
Monitor urine color; dark yellow indicates dehydration and need to increase water intake.
do_not: Do not wait until you feel thirsty to hydrate; thirst lags behind dehydration.
Do not push through dizziness, nausea, or headache—these are early heat illness signs.
Do not wear heavy or dark fabrics that trap heat.
watch_for: Headache, dizziness, weakness, rapid heartbeat.
Hot, flushed, dry skin (a sign of dangerous heatstroke).
Mental confusion, stumbling, or lack of sweating in extreme cases.
notes: Evaporation cools the body; wet a cloth and fan yourself when breeze is limited.
Electrolyte-rich foods (nuts, jerky, seeds) help maintain balance during intense heat.

entries.title: Sunburn Prevention & Field Relief
entries.summary: Reduce UV exposure and treat sunburn to prevent heat loss, infection, and worsening injury.
steps: Cover skin with clothing, hats, or improvised shades (bandanas, wraps, cloth layers).
Use natural shade whenever possible, such as trees, cliffs, or your shelter.
Moisten clothing in extreme heat to cool the skin while still blocking UV.
If burned, keep skin covered and out of direct sun.
Cool the area with clean water or damp cloths to relieve heat and soothe pain.
Drink extra water; sunburn increases dehydration.
do_not: Do not pop blisters; they protect underlying skin.
Do not scrub or peel burned skin.
Do not apply oily substances that trap heat during the first 24 hours.
watch_for: Large blisters, severe swelling, fever, or chills—signs of more serious injury.
Skin cracking or infection at the burn site.
notes: Cloud cover does NOT prevent UV exposure; up to 80% of UV can penetrate clouds.
Staying covered and shaded is more effective than relying on sunscreen you may not have.

entries.title: Flash Flood Safety
entries.summary: Recognize flood-prone areas and take immediate action when heavy rain threatens rising water.
steps: Avoid camping in dry washes, gullies, ravines, riverbeds, or basins, even if they appear safe.
Move to higher ground immediately if rain intensifies or you hear rushing water.
Listen for unusual roaring sounds or rapid changes in wind, which can indicate incoming water.
Cross water only at shallow, slow-moving points; use a stick to probe depth and stability.
If caught near rising water, climb to stable elevation rather than trying to outrun the flow.
do_not: Do not attempt to cross fast-moving water deeper than your ankles; currents can sweep you easily.
Do not camp within floodplains, even if weather is currently calm.
Do not assume rain needs to fall locally—storms miles upstream can cause sudden floods.
watch_for: Sudden water discoloration or debris in streams (sign of upstream flooding).
Rapidly rising water or damp soil that becomes saturated quickly.
Dark, fast-moving storm clouds over distant mountains or valleys.
notes: Flash floods remain one of the top killers in desert and canyon environments.
High ground is your best defense—always know where to move quickly.

entries.title: Staying Dry in Wet Weather
entries.summary: Retain body heat and protect gear by managing moisture, building cover, and minimizing water exposure.
steps: Create a rain cover using a tarp, poncho, large leaves, or improvised materials.
Pitch shelters on raised areas to avoid runoff and pooling.
Divert water by digging small drainage trenches away from the shelter entrance if necessary.
Store critical gear (fire starters, dry clothing, electronics) inside waterproof bags or wrapped in plastic.
Keep your feet dry by rotating socks and insulating them inside clothing if needed.
do_not: Do not let clothing become fully saturated; moisture accelerates heat loss.
Do not camp at the bottom of slopes where water naturally drains.
Do not leave fire-starting materials exposed; protect them early.
watch_for: Condensation buildup inside shelters; increase ventilation as needed.
Rain-driven wind that can push water sideways under shelter edges.
Hypothermia risk even in mild temperatures when wet and wind combine.
notes: Even light rain can soak you through after an hour—prioritize waterproofing early.
A dry base layer dramatically improves morale and survival chances.

entries.title: Surviving Strong Wind
entries.summary: Protect yourself and your shelter from high winds, falling branches, and debris.
steps: Seek natural windbreaks such as rock faces, thick bushes, or terrain depressions.
Reinforce shelter structures using extra branches, rocks, or stakes.
Remove or secure loose gear that can blow away or become dangerous.
Orient shelter openings away from prevailing wind direction.
Stay low to the ground on unstable ridges or exposed trails.
do_not: Do not camp beneath dead branches or leaning trees prone to falling in wind.
Do not stand near cliff edges during gusts.
Do not rely on lightweight shelters without reinforcement.
watch_for: Snapping sounds from trees, which may signal falling limbs.
Shifting wind direction; storms often change orientation rapidly.
Flying debris or dust, indicating increasing wind strength.
notes: Wind drastically increases heat loss—treat windy conditions like colder temperatures.
Using your pack or poncho as a temporary windblock helps reduce exposure while moving.

entries.title: Lightning Safety
entries.summary: Identify lightning hazards and adopt safe body positioning and shelter strategies during storms.
steps: Move off ridges, peaks, and exposed high ground immediately.
Avoid isolated tall trees; instead, shelter near shorter, uniform tree clusters if forested.
Keep at least 50–100 feet (15–30 m) away from tall objects like cliffs, towers, or solitary trees.
Separate from metal gear; place metal items several feet away.
Adopt the lightning position: crouch with feet together, minimize ground contact, tuck head, and keep hands on ears.
Spread out if in a group, keeping at least 50 feet between individuals to reduce multiple casualties.
do_not: Do not lie flat on the ground; this increases conduction exposure.
Do not shelter under isolated tall trees or rock overhangs that may conduct lightning.
Do not stand in or near water; move to dry ground immediately.
watch_for: Hair standing on end or tingling sensations—immediate lightning danger.
Sudden temperature drop or shifting wind before lightning storms.
Dark, fast-moving cloud systems forming an anvil shape.
notes: Lightning can strike miles from the storm core—take precautions early.
Crouching reduces your profile while minimizing ground contact, limiting conduction risk.

entries.title: Avalanche Awareness
entries.summary: Recognize avalanche-prone terrain and take steps to avoid dangerous snow conditions when traveling through mountains.
steps: Identify slopes between 30–45 degrees—these are the most avalanche-prone.
Look for signs of unstable snow: recent slides, cracking snow, hollow 'whump' sounds, or rapid warming.
Travel along ridgelines or low-angle terrain whenever possible.
Cross suspect slopes one at a time to minimize risk.
Have an escape plan before entering any avalanche terrain—note safe runouts or islands of safety.
do_not: Do not linger beneath cornices (overhanging snow ledges); they can break off without warning.
Do not traverse avalanche slopes after heavy snowfall, rapid warming, or strong wind loading.
Do not bunch up in groups while crossing risky areas.
watch_for: New snowfall of more than a few inches in a short time.
Sudden temperature increases, especially above freezing.
Wind-deposited slabs on leeward (downwind) slopes.
notes: Avalanches can occur even in shallow snowpacks under the right conditions.
If trapped, create an air pocket in front of your mouth and try to stay near the surface by swimming motions.

entries.title: Snow Shelter
entries.summary: Use snow as insulation to create a stable shelter that preserves body heat in frigid conditions.
steps: Choose an area with deep, stable snow away from avalanche paths and tree wells.
Dig a trench or hollow with enough room for your body and minimal excess space.
Create a roof using branches, skis, or poles, then cover heavily with snow for insulation.
Ventilate by poking a fist-sized hole in the roof to prevent carbon dioxide buildup.
Build an elevated sleeping surface using snow blocks or insulating materials to reduce heat loss.
Block the entrance with a backpack or snow mound while allowing minimal airflow.
do_not: Do not create a completely sealed shelter; ventilation is essential.
Do not build in unstable snow where collapse risk is high.
Do not use candles or stoves inside unless the shelter is large and adequately vented.
watch_for: Roof sagging or cracking—add reinforcement or exit immediately.
Moisture from melting snow on clothing or bedding.
Poor ventilation leading to dizziness or difficulty breathing.
notes: Snow shelters can be surprisingly warm if built correctly—snow is an excellent insulator.
Practice construction in safe conditions before relying on this technique in emergencies.

entries.title: Winter Conditions
entries.summary: Adapt to subfreezing temperatures by managing heat loss, fuel usage, snow hazards, and limited daylight.
steps: Start your day early; winter daylight hours are short and navigating in darkness increases risk.
Wear layered clothing with a windproof outer shell to minimize heat loss.
Keep extremities warm with insulated gloves, wool socks, and a hat that covers your ears.
Stay dry at all costs—snow that melts on clothing accelerates hypothermia.
Use snow as insulation in shelters by piling snow along windward walls or using it to block draft gaps.
Increase calorie intake; winter survival requires significantly more energy.
Monitor your pace to avoid sweating; remove layers briefly if you feel overheating.
do_not: Do not camp beneath trees loaded with heavy snow that may fall during nighttime warming.
Do not underestimate wind; even mild wind dramatically lowers effective temperature.
Do not walk directly into blowing snow without eye protection or improvised shielding.
watch_for: Frostbite on exposed skin, especially in wind.
Snow blindness caused by UV reflection; wear sunglasses or fashion eye slits from bark or cloth.
Rapid temperature drops around sunset, increasing hypothermia risk.
notes: In freezing conditions, keep water bottles insulated or upside down to prevent freezing at the opening.
Snow can be melted for water but requires heat; avoid eating snow directly, as it lowers core temperature.

entries.title: Spring Thaw Hazards
entries.summary: Navigate changing terrain, unstable ice, and increased flooding risks as temperatures rise during spring melt.
steps: Assume all ice is unstable; warming temperatures weaken ice even if it appears solid.
Avoid traveling across frozen lakes or rivers unless you can confirm thickness and stability.
Watch for swollen streams and rivers; melting snow can cause rapid and unpredictable flooding.
Travel on higher ground to avoid soft, collapsing banks and mud traps.
Monitor weather for warm rain, which speeds melting and increases flood potential.
Use trekking poles or sticks to test ground stability before stepping onto muddy or thawing areas.
do_not: Do not camp on riverbanks or low-lying areas during spring melt.
Do not cross streams that are rising quickly or carrying debris.
Do not assume morning ice is safe just because temperatures dropped overnight.
watch_for: Ground that appears solid but collapses when stepped on.
Vegetation leaning downstream—indicates strong water flow beneath or nearby.
Ice separating from the shore, creating hidden gaps.
notes: Spring is one of the most unpredictable seasons for foot travel; prioritize conservative navigation choices.
Snow bridges over streams collapse frequently during thaw—test carefully before crossing.

entries.title: Summer Heat Survival
entries.summary: Stay cool, hydrated, and protected from direct sunlight during extreme summer heat.
steps: Travel early in the morning or late in the afternoon; avoid peak heat hours.
Create shade using tarps, branches, reflective materials, or clothing layers.
Hydrate regularly, even when not thirsty; sip small amounts frequently.
Cover exposed skin with lightweight, breathable fabric to prevent sunburn and dehydration.
Rest in shaded or breezy locations to cool your core body temperature.
Use evaporative cooling by wetting a cloth and covering your neck, face, or pulse points.
do_not: Do not push through early symptoms of heat exhaustion such as headache or nausea.
Do not drink caffeine or alcohol in high heat; both accelerate dehydration.
Do not ration water too early; dehydration impairs judgment quickly.
watch_for: Rapid breathing, confusion, or lack of sweating—potential heatstroke.
Sunburn increasing heat absorption and dehydration.
Dry, cracked lips or dark urine indicating dehydration.
notes: When water sources are uncertain, conserve sweat, not water—move slowly and stay shaded.
High heat combined with wind can dehydrate you faster than you feel.

entries.title: Fall Weather Transition
entries.summary: Prepare for unstable temperatures, sudden windstorms, and early freezes during seasonal transition months.
steps: Carry additional layers even on warm days; fall temperatures drop rapidly after sunset.
Expect strong gusts and cold fronts—reinforce shelters earlier in the day.
Monitor cloud patterns for storm fronts; fall storms can form and move quickly.
Gather firewood early; wet fall conditions make dry tinder harder to find.
Insulate your sleeping area to prepare for sudden nighttime freezes.
do_not: Do not underestimate the temperature drop after sunset—prepare early.
Do not camp under trees shedding heavy branches; windstorms in fall often break dead limbs.
Do not leave gear unsecured; sudden gusts can carry it away.
watch_for: Darkening skies combined with sudden cold gusts—sign of incoming storm front.
Rapid barometric drops (ears popping or pressure sensations).
Unexpected frost on exposed surfaces in early morning.
notes: Fall is a transitional season; prepare for both warm daytime conditions and freezing nights.
Ground moisture increases as temperatures drop, so elevate sleeping gear whenever possible.

entries.title: Monsoon & Seasonal Heavy Rain Patterns
entries.summary: Recognize recurring storm cycles and protect yourself from sudden downpours, flash floods, and lightning common in monsoon regions.
steps: Observe daily patterns: monsoon storms often build in late afternoon but can vary regionally.
Set up camp early in the day on elevated, well-drained terrain.
Build trenches or drainage channels around shelters if heavy rain is expected.
Air out clothing and gear during morning dry periods to prevent mold and moisture buildup.
Prepare lightning-safe positions when thunderstorms are likely.
Avoid canyon systems, slot canyons, and desert washes during monsoon season.
do_not: Do not assume storms will follow predictable timing—monsoon systems shift quickly.
Do not shelter in caves or under rock overhangs prone to runoff or collapse.
Do not remain in narrow canyons even if the sky above appears clear.
watch_for: Towering cumulonimbus clouds forming rapidly in the afternoon.
Sudden humidity spikes and strong gusts of wind preceding storm rainfall.
Distant thunder, even faint—storms can send floodwaters miles ahead.
notes: Monsoon rains often arrive in cycles—plan activity windows in the calm periods.
Humidity reduces evaporative cooling; overheating can occur even during storms.

entries.title: Cloud Types & Weather Prediction
entries.summary: Recognize major cloud types and interpret what they indicate about incoming weather patterns.
steps: Cirrus Clouds (high altitude, thin and wispy): often signal fair weather but may indicate that a storm system is approaching within 24–48 hours.
Cirrostratus Clouds (milky, halo around sun/moon): usually precede warm fronts and can indicate steady precipitation coming.
Cirrocumulus Clouds (small ripples like fish scales): often appear in cold, fair weather but may precede a storm in tropical regions.
Altostratus Clouds (gray sheet covering sky): signal widespread moisture and usually precede prolonged rain or snow.
Altocumulus Clouds (white/gray patches): may signal thunderstorms later in the day when seen in warm, humid conditions.
Stratus Clouds (low, uniform gray): bring drizzle or light snow and reduce visibility; often accompany stable but damp weather.
Stratocumulus Clouds (low, lumpy): rarely lead to heavy precipitation; can indicate changing but mild weather.
Nimbostratus Clouds (thick, dark, covering sky): indicate continuous, steady rain or snow lasting hours.
Cumulus Clouds (puffy white with flat bases): fair weather clouds unless they grow vertically.
Cumulonimbus Clouds (towering, anvil-shaped): produce thunderstorms, lightning, hail, strong winds, and heavy rain. Dangerous for wilderness travel.
do_not: Do not ignore rapid vertical cloud growth; it often precedes thunderstorms.
Do not camp in exposed or low-lying areas when cumulonimbus clouds are forming.
Do not assume a clear morning guarantees a calm afternoon—cloud type changes can warn of storms hours ahead.
watch_for: Increasing thickness of clouds from high (cirrus) to low (stratus), signaling incoming fronts.
Anvil-shaped cumulonimbus tops spreading horizontally—a sign that a storm is actively developing.
Halo around sun or moon, which indicates ice crystals and often a warm front approaching.
notes: Learning cloud progression teaches you to predict changing weather without instruments.
Observation over time improves accuracy—practice reading the sky even in non-survival situations.

entries.title: Storm Indicators
entries.summary: Identify atmospheric, environmental, and visual signals that a storm is developing or approaching.
steps: Watch for rapid cloud thickening, especially cumulus clouds growing vertically into cumulonimbus formations.
Pay attention to sudden wind shifts; storms often pull in cooler air or create gust fronts.
Note changes in pressure: a feeling of fullness in the ears or sudden stillness often precedes storms.
Look for darkening skies, especially with greenish or yellowish tints indicating hail potential.
Listen for distant thunder, even faint—storms travel quickly, and lightning can strike far ahead of rain.
Smell for ozone or a 'metallic' scent, which can appear just before lightning-heavy storms.
Observe wildlife: birds flying low, insects disappearing, or sudden silence can correlate with incoming storms.
do_not: Do not ignore a rapid temperature drop; it likely signals a storm front moving in.
Do not stay in exposed areas like ridgelines or meadows once thunder is audible.
Do not assume storms only approach from the west; local wind patterns can vary.
watch_for: Shelf clouds or rolling formations at the leading edge of thunderstorms.
Cold gusts followed by sudden calm—the storm may be moments away.
Vertical lightning, which indicates strong updrafts and potential severe conditions.
notes: Storms can develop rapidly in mountains, deserts, and humid regions—anticipate rather than react.
Paying attention to small cues early gives you time to secure shelter or relocate safely.

entries.title: Beaufort Wind Scale
entries.summary: Use the Beaufort scale to estimate wind speed based on its visible effects on the environment.
steps: Force 0 (Calm): Smoke rises vertically; no wind movement.
Force 1 (Light Air): Smoke drifts slightly; leaves barely move.
Force 2 (Light Breeze): Leaves rustle; small twigs move.
Force 3 (Gentle Breeze): Flags extend slightly; leaves and small branches move.
Force 4 (Moderate Breeze): Dust and loose paper lift; small branches sway.
Force 5 (Fresh Breeze): Small trees begin to sway; waves form on lakes.
Force 6 (Strong Breeze): Large branches move; umbrellas difficult to use.
Force 7 (Near Gale): Whole trees move; walking becomes challenging.
Force 8 (Gale): Twigs break off trees; progress on foot is difficult.
Force 9 (Severe Gale): Slight structural damage possible; visibility reduced.
Force 10 (Storm): Trees uprooted in places; heavy structural effects.
Force 11 (Violent Storm): Widespread structural damage; extremely dangerous.
Force 12 (Hurricane): Devastation; complete loss of structural integrity in many areas.
do_not: Do not travel on exposed ridges or open water above Force 6 conditions.
Do not camp near trees during gale-force winds or higher.
Do not underestimate Force 3–4 winds when combined with cold, as wind chill increases dramatically.
watch_for: Tree movement—one of the easiest ways to estimate wind strength.
Whitecaps forming on lakes (typically start at Force 4–5).
Loose debris lifting from the ground, which signals dangerous wind speeds.
notes: You can estimate wind speed visually without instruments, critical when planning shelter placement and travel.
Wind often increases before major weather systems—use the Beaufort scale to detect early storm escalation.
